awd_titl_txt: CIF:Medium:Collaborative Research: Geometric Network Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The proliferation of communication networks means that their efficiency and security now affects almost all aspects of our daily lives. At the societal level, reliable and efficient networks are of central importance to technological development, national economic growth and national defense. In light of this, the problem of understanding fundamental information limits of networked devices is more acute now than ever. Unfortunately, it has been a longstanding challenge in information theory to systematically extend its success beyond classical point-to-point exchanges of information. Despite significant research effort since the inception of the  field in 1948, the information limits for most network settings, even for networks as fundamental as a three node relay channel, have remained open to date.

This project aims to change the way many network problems are analyzed today in information theory. Traditional information-theoretic approaches for quantifying fundamental performance limits of networks often fail because the current toolset of information theory is not sufficiently refined to characterize tensions that emerge in networks due to competing objectives.  Looking beyond traditional methods, this project will study the role that inequalities from geometric and functional analysis can play in characterizing tensions between information measures. The research project will be complemented with a strong inter-university education program, which includes joint and collaborative student and post-doctoral researcher advising.

por.por_cntn:
Information-theoretic approaches for quantifying fundamental performance limits of networks often fail because the traditional toolset is not sufficiently refined to characterize tensions that emerge in networks due to competing objectives. This project sought to address this through the development of new techniques, with efficacy demonstrated through new applications.  

Broadly speaking, the outcomes of this project cover three complementary topics: (i) extremal inequalities involving information measures such as entropies, which greatly generalize their traditional counterparts; (ii) information-theoretic inequalities with statistical applications, including Bayesian Cramer--Rao-type bounds; and (iii) leveraging geometric aspects of distributed computing problems to both accelerate and make more robust certain large-scale computing applications, such as those encountered in machine learning.

For the first topic, we developed a general family of sharp entropy inequalities that interpolate between the well-known (forward) Brascamp--Lieb and (reverse) Barthe inequalities, and further established a precise characterization of the extremizers. This led to several new results in network information theory, and also illuminated precise connections between entropic and geometric inequalities, such as the entropy power inequality and the Brunn--Minkowski inequality.

For the second topic, we derived a new family of Cramer-Rao-type bounds, which enable simple derivation of impossibility results for statistical estimation problems.  For example, this allows one to bound the performance of any statistical estimator (not just unbiased ones) in terms of a simple Fisher information term.  This is important for estimation problems over networks, where the Fisher information term may be easier to bound directly than one involving mutual information.

For the third topic, we exploited geometric aspects of certain large-scale computational problems to efficiently solve them on an unreliable and distributed network (e.g., the cloud). The results obtained are directly applicable to resource provisioning in serverless systems, which are projected to be the dominant cloud-computing service in the near future.

The above findings have been presented at international research symposia and published in scholarly journals.

Beyond scientific and technical accomplishments, this project contributed to the professional development of undergraduate and graduate students at UC Berkeley, and also to that of a postdoctoral researcher. Of the project participants, two have gone on to tenure-track academic positions, and two have taken senior scientific positions in industry.
